scenarios.title: School Zone Situation
scenarios.situation: You're driving at 50 km/h when you notice a school zone sign. Children are playing near the road. What should you do?

choices.text: Maintain current speed if no children are crossing
choices.feedback: Incorrect. School zones require reduced speed regardless of visible children.

choices.text: Slow down to 30 km/h and stay alert
choices.feedback: Correct! School zones require reduced speed and increased vigilance at all times.

choices.text: Honk to warn children and continue
choices.feedback: Wrong. Honking can startle children. Always reduce speed in school zones.

scenarios.explanation: School zones require drivers to reduce speed to 30 km/h and remain extra vigilant, as children may suddenly enter the roadway.

scenarios.title: Pedestrian Crossing
scenarios.situation: You approach a pedestrian crossing. A person is standing on the curb looking like they want to cross. What do you do?

choices.text: Speed up to pass before they step out
choices.feedback: Dangerous! Always give way to pedestrians at crossings.

choices.text: Slow down and be prepared to stop
choices.feedback: Correct! Always be ready to stop for pedestrians at crossings.

choices.text: Continue at same speed, they'll wait
choices.feedback: Wrong. Pedestrians have right of way at marked crossings.

scenarios.explanation: Pedestrians have priority at marked crossings. Always slow down and be prepared to stop.

scenarios.title: Overtaking Decision
scenarios.situation: You're on a two-lane highway. A slow truck is ahead. There's a dashed line on your side. What's the safest action?

choices.text: Check mirrors, signal, overtake when clear
choices.feedback: Correct! Always check mirrors, signal, and ensure the lane is clear before overtaking.

choices.text: Overtake immediately without checking
choices.feedback: Extremely dangerous! Always check before changing lanes.

choices.text: Follow closely to pressure the truck
choices.feedback: Wrong and dangerous. Maintain safe following distance.

scenarios.explanation: Overtaking requires checking mirrors, signaling intentions, and ensuring the opposite lane is clear for a safe distance.

scenarios.title: Heavy Rain Driving
scenarios.situation: It's raining heavily. The car ahead suddenly brakes. Your normal following distance is 2 seconds. What should you do?

choices.text: Brake gently and increase following distance to 4 seconds
choices.feedback: Correct! In rain, double your following distance and brake smoothly.

choices.text: Brake hard to stop quickly
choices.feedback: Wrong. Hard braking on wet roads can cause skidding.

choices.text: Maintain distance and continue normally
choices.feedback: Incorrect. Wet conditions require increased following distance.

scenarios.explanation: In wet conditions, stopping distances increase significantly. Double your following distance and brake gently to avoid skidding.

scenarios.title: Ambulance Approaching
scenarios.situation: You hear an ambulance siren approaching from behind while driving in traffic. What should you do?

choices.text: Pull to the right and stop
choices.feedback: Correct! Always pull to the right side and stop for emergency vehicles.

choices.text: Speed up to clear the way
choices.feedback: Wrong. Speeding up is dangerous. Pull over and stop.

choices.text: Change lane suddenly to the left
choices.feedback: Incorrect. Always move to the right for emergency vehicles.

scenarios.explanation: When emergency vehicles approach with sirens, safely pull to the right side of the road and stop until they pass.

scenarios.title: Roundabout Entry
scenarios.situation: You're approaching a roundabout. A car is already circulating inside from your right. What do you do?

choices.text: Speed up to enter before the other car
choices.feedback: Dangerous! Always give way to traffic already in the roundabout.

choices.text: Slow down and give way to traffic in the roundabout
choices.feedback: Correct! Traffic already circulating in the roundabout has priority.

choices.text: Stop completely and wait for all traffic to clear
choices.feedback: Too cautious. Yield but enter when safe.

scenarios.explanation: At roundabouts, you must give way to traffic from the right that is already circulating. Enter when there's a safe gap.

scenarios.title: Parking on a Hill
scenarios.situation: You need to park your car facing uphill on a street with a curb. How should you position your wheels?

choices.text: Turn wheels to the left, away from curb
choices.feedback: Correct! Turn wheels left (away from curb) when facing uphill so the car rolls back into the curb if brakes fail.

choices.text: Turn wheels to the right, toward curb
choices.feedback: Wrong for uphill parking. This is for downhill parking.

choices.text: Keep wheels straight
choices.feedback: Incorrect. Angled wheels provide safety if brakes fail.

scenarios.explanation: When parking uphill with a curb, turn your wheels away from the curb (left). If the brakes fail, the car will roll back and the rear wheels will stop against the curb.

scenarios.title: Tire Blowout
scenarios.situation: You're driving at 100 km/h when you experience a sudden tire blowout. What's the safest immediate action?

choices.text: Brake hard immediately
choices.feedback: Dangerous! Hard braking can cause loss of control.

choices.text: Hold steering firmly, ease off gas, brake gently
choices.feedback: Correct! Maintain control, gradually slow down, then pull over safely.

choices.text: Swerve to the shoulder immediately
choices.feedback: Wrong. Sudden movements can cause a rollover.

scenarios.explanation: During a blowout, hold the steering wheel firmly, ease off the accelerator, and brake gently once you've regained control. Then safely pull to the shoulder.

scenarios.title: Fog Visibility
scenarios.situation: You're driving in dense fog with visibility under 100 meters. What lights should you use?

choices.text: High beam headlights
choices.feedback: Wrong. High beams reflect off fog, reducing visibility.

choices.text: Low beam headlights and fog lights
choices.feedback: Correct! Low beams and fog lights provide best visibility in fog.

choices.text: Only fog lights
choices.feedback: Insufficient. Use both low beams and fog lights.

scenarios.explanation: In fog, use low beam headlights and fog lights. High beams reflect off the fog particles and actually reduce visibility.

scenarios.title: Brake Failure
scenarios.situation: Your brakes fail while driving downhill. What should you do first?

choices.text: Pump the brake pedal and shift to lower gear
choices.feedback: Correct! Pumping can build pressure, and lower gear provides engine braking.

choices.text: Turn off the engine immediately
choices.feedback: Wrong. This disables power steering and is more dangerous.

choices.text: Pull the handbrake hard
choices.feedback: Too aggressive. This can lock rear wheels and cause skidding.

scenarios.explanation: If brakes fail, pump the pedal to build pressure, shift to a lower gear for engine braking, and gradually apply the parking brake if needed.

scenarios.title: Traffic Light Turning Yellow
scenarios.situation: You're approaching an intersection at 50 km/h. The light turns yellow when you're 20 meters away. What should you do?

choices.text: Speed up to cross before red
choices.feedback: Dangerous! Yellow means prepare to stop, not speed up.

choices.text: Brake safely and stop if possible
choices.feedback: Correct! Yellow light means stop if you can do so safely.

choices.text: Continue at same speed
choices.feedback: Wrong. Always prepare to stop at yellow light.

scenarios.explanation: A yellow light means stop if you can do so safely. Only proceed if stopping would be dangerous (e.g., car too close behind).

scenarios.title: Merging onto Highway
scenarios.situation: You're on an entrance ramp merging onto a busy highway. Traffic is heavy. What's the best approach?

choices.text: Stop at the end of ramp and wait for a gap
choices.feedback: Dangerous! Stopping on the ramp creates a hazard.

choices.text: Match highway speed and merge smoothly when safe
choices.feedback: Correct! Speed up to match traffic and merge when there's a safe gap.

choices.text: Force your way in, they must give way
choices.feedback: Wrong. Highway traffic has right of way.

scenarios.explanation: When merging, accelerate in the ramp to match highway speed, signal, and merge smoothly into a safe gap. Don't stop on the ramp.

scenarios.title: Parallel Parking
scenarios.situation: You need to parallel park in a tight space. What's the correct sequence?

choices.text: Pull alongside, reverse at 45¬∞, straighten when aligned
choices.feedback: Correct! This is the proper parallel parking technique.

choices.text: Reverse straight back into the space
choices.feedback: Won't work. You need to angle the car to fit.

choices.text: Drive forward into the space from the front
choices.feedback: Impossible for parallel parking. Must reverse in.

scenarios.explanation: Parallel parking: Pull alongside the front car, reverse while turning wheels toward curb at 45¬∞, then straighten when aligned.

scenarios.title: Hydroplaning
scenarios.situation: Your car starts hydroplaning on a wet road. You feel the steering become light. What do you do?

choices.text: Ease off accelerator, don't brake, steer smoothly
choices.feedback: Correct! Let the car slow naturally and steer gently to regain traction.

choices.text: Brake hard to regain control
choices.feedback: Wrong! Braking during hydroplaning can cause complete loss of control.

choices.text: Accelerate to power through
choices.feedback: Dangerous! This will make hydroplaning worse.

scenarios.explanation: During hydroplaning, ease off the accelerator and avoid braking or sudden steering. Let the car slow down naturally to regain traction.

scenarios.title: Accident Scene
scenarios.situation: You come upon a fresh accident on the highway. What's your first priority?

choices.text: Rush to help injured people immediately
choices.feedback: Not first priority. Ensure your safety and call emergency services first.

choices.text: Stop safely, turn on hazards, call emergency services
choices.feedback: Correct! First ensure safety, then call for help before assisting.

choices.text: Stop in the middle of the road to block traffic
choices.feedback: Dangerous! This could cause another accident.

scenarios.explanation: At an accident scene: Pull over safely, activate hazards, call emergency services (155), then assist if you're trained and it's safe.
